posts.post_content:
For 9 mana you have a killer creature. That sounds about right, until you realize that you can pay in installments! So what if your opponent killed it? That just means it's a great big threat that they must answer to, and that's good for you!  
  
Also, it's not as annoying to lose a creature that you can replace by paying only 2-mana and starting the clock again quite easily without tapping out of mana for counters. This is a great card, and I foresee fun things to happen with it on the field.  
  
Makes you a big target in multiplayer though. Even bigger than [Luminarch Ascension](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Luminarch Ascension), I'd wager.
posts.html:

Also, it's not as annoying to lose a creature that you can replace by paying only 2-mana and starting the clock again quite easily without tapping out of mana for counters. This is a great card, and I foresee fun things to happen with it on the field.

Makes you a big target in multiplayer though. Even bigger than Luminarch Ascension, I'd wager.

posts.post_content: @Final\_Fortune: Nope, it means that you take a bonus turn after each of your opponent's. That includes during a duel, so that the order once this thing powers up goes You (level-up turn)-Opponent-You (bonus)-You (regular)-Opponent-You (bonus)-You (regular)-Opponent...etc. Essentially, it means that you get to play a Time Warp once per go-around.
posts.html:
@Final_Fortune: Nope, it means that you take a bonus turn after each of your opponent's.
